analyzeResult.content:
vey of members of the college class of 1992 shows that the students are get- ting less financial assistance from the Federal Government and are increas- ingly interested in college as a way to land a high-paying job.
The survey of last fall's incoming college freshmen was taken by the American Council on Education and the Higher Education Research Insti- tute at the University of California at Los Angeles.that
The proportion of freshmen who identified their political views as con- servative or far right was 22 percent, the highest in the 23 years the survey has been taken. But large majorities of students took liberal positions when asked about specific issues like pollu- tion, disarmament, abortion and con- sumer protection.
'Liberal' Seen as 'Impotent'
"It's because of the beating the word liberal has taken," said Kenneth C. Green of U.C.L.A., associate director of the survey. "A lot of them think liberal means impotent."
On the other hand, the survey found
The students get less aid but seek bigger jobs.
students taking increasingly conserva- tive stands on matters related to crime and the death penalty. And two-thirds of the freshmen agreed that the best way to control acquired immune defi- ciency syndrome was through wide- spread, mandatory testing, while 71 percent agreed that employers should be allowed to test employees or job ap- plicants for drugs.
The findings are based on question- naires filled out last fall by 308,007 freshmen entering 585 two- and four- year colleges and universities. The re- sults have a margin of sampling error of plus or minus two percentage points.
Rise Seen in Smokers
The number of students who said they were frequent smokers could have reversed a 22-year decline. In 1966, 17 percent of the freshmen said they were frequent smokers. That percentage fell steadily to 9 percent in 1987 but rose to 10 percent among those entering col- lege last fall.
In addition, 11 percent of freshmen, a record high, said they frequently felt depressed, while 56 percent rated their emotional health as above average, down from 57 percent in 1987.
A record proportion of freshmen said they were interested in pursuing ad- vanced degrees: 59 percent, as against 48 percent in 1980. And a record 73 per-
College SCAN 11.8%
1
New College Freshmen Show Shifts in Attitudes
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) - A sur- | cent indicated "making more money" was a very important factor in the decision to attend college.
At the same time, interest in entering the business world declined slightly to 24 percent, from 25 percent in 1987, after two decades of steady gains. Sur- vey officials said the results "suggest that student interest in business ca- reers may have reached a plateau after the dramatic increases of the 1970's and 1980's."
The survey also found that Federal financial aid at college had eroded. Only 16 percent of freshmen entering school last fall took part in the Govern- ment's major aid program, Pell, grants, for students from low- and mid- dle-income families. That was the low- est level since the survey began and less than half the 32 percent who re- ceived Pell grants in 1980.
Students reported greater reliance on family contributions, savings, loans and college-sponsored grants. For in- stance, 20 percent of the students re- ceived college-sponsored grants, up from 13 percent in 1980.
Grants for Vocational Students
Mr. Green said: "Fewer students at college are getting aid, and campuses are picking up part of the burden. One of the reasons tuition is going up is that institutions have to find the aid money from someplace."
But the lobbying arm of the College Board, a New York-based testing serv- ice, said the amount of aid distributed through the Pell grants actually rose nearly 57 percent from 1980 to 1988, or 17 percent with inflation taken into ac- count.
But in the same period, the aid be- came more sharply aimed at the needi- est post-secondary students, many of whom shun college in favor of voca- tional schools that teach cosmetology, art, drama, auto mechanics, business skills or other trades.
Victoria Tripp, an Education Depart- ment spokeswoman, said 11 percent of Pell money went to vocational students in 1980, as against 27 percent in 1988. "That figure will increase to one-third in the early 1990's," she predicted. "The money is targeted to those stu- dents, and there has been a prolifera- tion of those schools."
Reagan Leaves Hospital
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (Reuters) - President Reagan returned to the White House today, a day after under- going surgery on his left hand. Mr. Rea- gan waved his bandaged hand upon leaving the Walter Reed Army Medical Center here, where the operation, to correct a curvature in the ring finger of his left hand, was peris med. He was not wearing a sling, although reports before the operation said he wild have to wear one. He is expected to re- sume a full schedule of activity this week, his next-to-last as President.
I
